an4.40:1.1: Then Udāyī the brahmin went up to the Buddha, … and asked him,
an4.40:1.4: Nor do I criticize all sacrifices. …
an4.40:1.5: Take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of animals are slaughtered.
an4.40:1.6: I don’t praise that kind of violent sacrifice.
an4.40:2.1: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of animals are not slaughtered.
an4.40:2.2: I do praise that kind of non-violent sacrifice; for example, a regular gift as an ongoing family sacrifice.
an4.40:3.1: The kind of sacrifice that’s allowable and timely,
an4.40:4.1: The Buddhas—<j>who have drawn back the veil from the world,
an4.40:4.4: as they are expert in sacrifice.
an4.40:5.1: When you’ve prepared a suitable offering,
an4.40:5.2: whether as sacrifice or for ancestors,
an4.40:5.4: in the fertile field of spiritual practitioners.
an4.40:6.2: to those worthy of a religious donation,
an4.40:6.4: and even the deities are pleased.
an4.40:7.2: sacrifices like this, with a mind of letting go,
